case.state: HK416. Please remember this extraordinary name.
45? ...45, I know you can fucking hear me. What kind of simulation did you drop me into?
45? ...45, I know you can fucking hear me. What kind of simulation is this?
45? ...45, I know you can hear me, damnit. What fucking kind of simulation is this?
I prevail, as always.
Another victory to my name.
Operation proceeding as expected.
All according to plan.
Everything proceeding as expected.
As expected of the finest.
I prevail, as expected.
What did you expect when trying to compete with IOP's finest?
And that is what happens when you go against IOP's finest work.
One more victim of IOP's finest.
I usually only see results this devastating after using grenades.
I usually only cause this much devastation with my grenades.
As an operator, I've seen many impressively built male physiques. Let's see how you stack up, ja?
I've seen a lot of impressive physiques as an operator. I wonder how you'll compare.
I wonder why UMP45 hasn't responded yet. Is that part of the simulation parameters?
No response from UMP45, yet. Is that part of the simulation?
No reply message from UMP45 so far... is that a simulation requirement?
Hmm... I need to check in for routine maintenance at Safehouse Bravo-Charlie in... about four days...
Now that I think about it... this simulation feels a bit different from the regular combat sims.
I wish I could've brought my weapon into this simulation.

What they say to a female NPC who has lost a round

What the character says when a male character is about to remove the last piece of clothing covering their chest. For NPCs, this is a clothing element on the "upper" location, with the "important" type.
A female character is about to remove a clothing item with the type "minor".
What the character says after the male character's crotch is visible, and has a size value of "medium".
What the character says after the major item has been taken off.
What the character says after the male character's crotch is visible, and has a size value of "large".
